{{Merge to|Third Position|discuss=Talk:Third Position#Merger proposal|date=July 2012}} '''Syncretic politics''' or '''spectral-syncretic''' is used to refer to politics outside of the conventional [[Left–right politics|left-right political spectrum]], the term is used by some scholars to describe the political nature of [[fascism]].<ref>Roger Griffin. ''Fascism''. Oxford, England, UK: Oxford University Press, 1995. Pp. 8, 307.</ref><ref>Aristotle A. Kallis. ''The fascism reader''. New York, New York, USA: Routledge, 2003. Pp. 71</ref><ref>Blamires, Cyprian, ''World Fascism: a Historical Encyclopedia, Volume 1'' (Santa Barbara, California: ABC-CLIO, Inc., 2006) p. 14, 561.</ref> The [[Falange]] of [[Spain]] presented itself as syncretic.<ref>Paloma Aguilar. ''Memory in Amnesia: The Role of the Spanish Civil War in the Transition to Democracy''. Oxford, England, UK; New York, New York, USA: Berghahn Books, 2002. Pp. </ref> [[Falangism]] has attacked both the left and the right as its "enemies", declaring itself to be neither left nor right, but a [[third position]].<ref>Roger Griffin (ed). Fascism. Oxford, England, UK; New York, New York, USA: Oxford University Press, 1995. Pp. 189.</ref> ==See also== * [[Political spectrum]]
